description.text:
My brother wanted a keg handle that resembled my cat-in-law, so I mixed the following two things:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:623817

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:182091

You just need to glue a 3/8 inch threaded nut into the bottom and you're good to go.

Just thought it would be a good idea to upload some of my favourite parts: nuts and bolts!
The trick is to pause the printer at the right time, insert the metal nut or bolt and continue printing, encasing the parts!
For the bolt I made a very thin shell that I remove after it's done.

title: Anet A8 Improved X-belt Tensioner with GT2 pulley
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a remix of the x-belt tensioner by freemark with a wider opening for using it with a GT2 pulley. I used a pulley with 16 teeth. In addition to the pulley you need one M3x20 screw and one M3 nut (better a lock nut) to mount the GT2 pulley to the printed part. And also two M3x25 screws (better thumb screws) and two more M3 nuts for mounting the part properly to the printer.

description.text: Students Created a Logo after doing a personal branding lesson.

I needed a hook to hang a garbage bag in my truck, and I never use the 12v plugs. This fits right in there.

Your filament will determine how good this does. PLA will flex a bit, so it is probably better for the pressure against the sides.

If you print this laying down (the flat back, which also acts as a place you can shim with a nonconductive item for a tighter fit) you may have better success, as printing vertically risks more possible delamination breakage along a layer. To do this you'll have to print with supports though.

title: Shopping Cart Keychain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D printed Cart Keychain. The idea is to attach this to your keychain and stick it in a shopping cart instead of a quarter. I measured it up to match a NIS 5 Shekel Coin, which is similar to most international "standards".

The first version was designed in Tinkercad, and I printed it successfully (and it works in the cart very well)

But, The second one is made in Fusion 360, I improved the design and added a filet. Currently, it's extruded till 1.3 mm, but should be between 2.4 to 2.6 to work properly.

Key V5, is the corrected version, I made it a little longer, moved the keyhole in a bit more, and fixed the filet. This version hasn't been printed yet, though.

If you like this design, please cosider tipping. paypal.me/AParshan

Here is my website: http://www.aviparshan.com

I make Android Apps: https://play.google.com/store/apps/dev?id=7646777248290288031

This necessities pack for the TronXY X1 printer contains small parts I lacked or were in need of for upgrades, which weren't available yet. Check out my videos for more information: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7eCfWzUNmLfCMWAiAfs4h9a9XASoXD2v

M5 Pillar
Normally, there should be enough in the kit, but my kit lacked 8 of them. They are used to ensure the distance between the wheels and the holders on the X and Y axes. If you have the chance of getting parts printed anyways, go for https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275654 for the X-Axis and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203872 for the print bed directly.

M5 Washer
I used some of these washers for making the bearings in the https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2020468 belt tightener less wobbly.

M5 Angeled Pillar
Pretty similar to the other M5 Pillar, this one comes with one side angled by 12°. They were designed to successfully use https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2018331 on the TronXY X1.

This thing gets extended with future necessities when I am in need of them and design them anyways ;-)

title: BZB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: Since writing this I have replaced the flex-coupler with a u-joint and the combination of the BZB and the u-joint has is providing an even better result

This upgrade is intended for a stock Tevo Tarantula with a z- rod that is found to wobble and where the user notices z-banding.

First checks.

The Kit Tarantula implements a stepper motor at the top with a z-rod hanging from a flexible coupler. Before you go through the effort of printing and installing this upgrade, do the following verifications

  1. Ensure that the acrylic bracket on which the z-stepper motor mounts is exactly square to the frame. (as seen from the side) Use a small square to measure this. If it is not square ensure that the horizontal extrusion is flush against the vertical extrusions on both sides. If it is flush but still not square, use a shim on one side of mounting screws along the length of the bracket to shim it until it is square. Fasten the t-nuts. Verify again.
  2. Measure the distance of your z-rod from the vertical post. It should be the same at the top and at the bottom. This should be verified from the side view as well as from the back view. Adjust the motor position on the bracket and the lead nut mount on the X-frame until this is true.
  3. Move the z position in big steps by using the stepper motor. Position yourself so that you can see the flex couple turning. If the flex couple wobbles then do the following. Tie the X axis extrusion assembly to the top bar with a piece of thin rope. Undo the flex coupling grub screws. Screw the z lead screw manually downwards to remove it from the coupler. Remount the flex coupling to the stepper motor axle. The axle must go only as deep as the non flexible part of the coupler. Tighten at least one of the grub screws. Now align the lead screw with the coupler and screw it by hand to it is inserted into the coupler. The lead screw must go only as deep as the non flexible part of the coupler. Lock all the grub screws on the coupler. Check that coupler wobble has been resolved. Repeat step 2 above.

Remove the rope

Position the lead nut about halfway up the travel range (i.e. approx 100mm above the bed) Move the z-distance of the printing head by using the stepper motor while watching the bottom of the lead screw. If the lead screw centre line is projecting a small circle (wobble), read further. If not then you should be good.
If you had to make notable changes in any of steps steps 1 to 3 above, do a test print. If you still have notable z-banding and you have notable wobbling of the lead screw, then you may try this upgrade.
Note that this mod will not work if you support the bottom end of the z-rod with a bearing. In that case you will be better off with an oldham.

Extra Materials required
4 M4 x 12mm socket head screws
4 M4 washers (another four is optional)
3.9 mm drill bit (for those living in the imperial countries a 5/32" bit will do the trick)
3 mm drill bit (1/8" is good here)
Synthetic grease

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have printed mine using e-SUN PLA +. The Filament needs to be soft enough to be able to for the screws to cut their own thread into the material

Part preparation

Print the three stl's files provided. I have printed mine using a 0.2mm layer height
Remove all burr's and rough edges, unexpected protrusions, etc, from the prints using a hobby knife.
Starting with the largest print from BZB_1.stl, open up all three holes with the 3.9mm (5/32") drill bit. An M4 screw should now be able to turn freely in the holes without notable play.
Next, take the print from the BZB_2.stl and open up ONLY the holes on the two lower profile of the 4 sides, NOT on the two sides that has a miniature 'gable" look to it. Again, an M4 screw should be able to turn freely in the opened up holes.
Lastly, take the print from the BZB_3 file and open the 4 lead nut mounting holes with the 3mm drill (1/8").

Dry-fit

Take the print from the BZB-3 and insert it into the BZB-2 with the two holes on the side facing the lower profile sides of BZB-2. Take an M4 x 12 Screw with a washer and screw it into the one side. The screw should self tap into the plastic. Don't go all the way. Repeat on the other side. Now adjust the screw to make sure that the BZB-3 will stay centre with notable gaps between the two parts . The BZB should be able to freely tilt about 10 degrees without hitting or rubbing against BZB-2. If there is space you can add a couple of optional washers between the two parts (in my case I still had a bit of and elephants foot problem, so the optional washers did not fit)
Take the assembled part and insert it into BZB-1. The bottom of the assembled part (BZB 2&3) should face away from the bottom of BZB-1. Align the holes and use the remaining screws and washers. If you have space add washers in between. Again, the BZB-2&3 assembly should be able to tilt freely in BZB-1 without rubbing against the sides (until it stops against BZB-1)
If you are happy with the above assembly then remove the lead screw and nut from the printer. Remember to use a rope to tie the X-axis extrusion assembly to the top bar. (or else it may crash into the bed)

Final assembly

Remove BZB-2&3 from BZB-1.
Take the original four M3 screws and nuts to remount the lead nut into the assembly. It must be inserted from the bottom and the screws from the recessed holes. Fasten the nuts. (M3 nuts against the bottom of the lead nut)
Undo the two M4 screws on the BZB 2&3 assembly by about 3 mm but without removing them from the assembly. Use a thin wire or toothpick and add lubricant to the threads just below the head. Don't let any lubricant get into the inner plastic part threads. Fasten the screws and adjust whilst checking for fee movement.
Insert the BZB-2&3 assembly into BZB-1 and assemble. Lubricate the outside parts of the threads without getting lubricant on the holes in the inner part. Check and adjust for free movement.
Thread the lead screw through the mounted lead nut and mount on the printer. Repeat steps 1 to 3 above.

The assembly is 5 mm longer and wider that the original bracket with the screw heads protruding as well. Ensure that all moving parts will still clear the assembly

Keep your fingers crossed and do a test print.
Let me know if you have any comments

Replacing the standard lead nut mount on a stock Tevo Tarantula

This is my first design using a 3-D design package(Design Spark Mechanical) It was designed with the intent to replace the standard bracket and assembly with this one, without having to do major readjustments.

The rationale behind the design is when you have a bent rod the angle at which the lead nut is positioned on the threads will change as the rod is being turned through 360 degrees. When the lead nut is fixed to the printing head platform, the forces on the platform will result in the lowering and lifting the head angle as it goes through the 360 degrees. In some cases it may also move the head most notably in the Y- direction as the beam is torqued on the slight flex provided by the rubber wheels. When the torque force is down the head is pushed closer to the previous layer and the new layer will be printed wider, and as the platform is torqued up the head is moved further from the previous layer the new layer will print thinner, resulting in the typical z-banding with peaks and valleys where the distance between peaks correlates with the amount the platform moves in the z-direction with one 360 degrees turn.
This design will mostly eliminate the torque forces on the platform as a result of the lead nut changing its horizontal angle, allowing mainly the z- motion to be transferred to the platform.

Ready for the lead nut to be mounted From left to right BZB 1 2 &3 as well as the additional materials required Opening up the holes for the lead nut to be mounted Opening up the holes for the pivot screws in BZB-2 First functional prototype mounted

So based on a variety of reasons (too long to go into here) I opted to build a UConduit frame mostly due to it's cost and how easy it is to modify to be an enclosed printer (for ABS etc).

This is largely due to my dislike of all the extra finishing effort and brittleness of PLA as the printer I am currently using (a Robo R1) doesn't seem to like to print in anything BUT PLA.

The UConduit info is fairly old, but I saw that the HyperCube is it's more expensive cousin (t-slot gets pricey compared to conduit).

That being said, I remixed the mounting bracket from the HyperCube and combined it with the bolt pattern of the jhead holder in the UConduit files. I have printed this but I am in the midst of a build so pics will be coming soon.

*Note: I included the clamp as well, though that is an unmodified version of the part from
https://www.thingiverse.com/download:2751284

title: Nexus 5 holder for Lexus IS250 IS350 IS220d IS200d

description.text:
I just designed this on tinkercad https://tinkercad.com/
For my IS250. It has three printable parts. The main board has 5 holes. Two holes hold the hooks that go into the trim and three holes hold the arms that hold the phone in place. Nexus 5 phone just slides in without a cover but also can be pushed in if you have a cover on the phone.
The only small problem is that you have to glue in the hooks and arms into the main board. I used super glue.
printed it on my sumpod printer. need superglue to hold the hooks and arms in the mainboard.

title: LJ18A3-8-Z/BX 18mm Inductive Proximity Sensor Mount for JG Aurora A3 Anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a very sturdy mount for an inductive proximity sensor. This connects the LJ18A3-8-Z/BX to the JG Aurora A3 and likely to many other models.

This version allows easy access for extruder cleaning and covers more area of the bed (compared to some others) when auto-leveling.

I had to replace one of the fan screws (M3x20) with a slightly longer one (M3x25). Fortunately, my JG Aurora kit came with plenty of extra hardware.

UPDATE 5/29/17:
Added Alt1 & Alt2 which allows room for some custom fan ducts and for additional printer compatibility.

title: Prosthetic Hand to Rope Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This prototype attachment and the prosthetic hand adapter it is designed for have been made in the engineering department at Seattle Pacific University. The objective of the piece is to allow single directional movement of a climbing rope in order to assist in belaying with a Grigri or similar assisted belay device. The assisted belay device will keep the part from bearing too much stress; however, as a 3D printed part it is not fit for use outside demonstration.
The hexagonal bottom is secured into the adapter so that the orientation of the top allows movement of the rope across the palm and in between the thumb and finger. The teeth inside the tube where the rope is inserted are oriented to allow the rope to move one way, but catch if it moves the opposite direction, as one side is slanted and the other flat. If used on the break hand the piece should slide freely toward the belay device and catch as it is pulled away. It should be noted that with PLA these teeth wear down very quickly.

title: Joycon & Knuckles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Be ready for the brawl with this pair of accesories!

The joycons themselves are so packed with functionalities that improving them is almost impossible! That's why I decided to come up with this aesthetic add-on, which also provides a very comfortable grip. I'm sure it will be nice to have when ARMS comes out... also, you will look cooler than an ice cube!.

This design has been tested for good printability. In order to get a good print so the knuckles fit the joycons smoothly, I designed a version with support included. The support comes off easily and it can be removed by pushing (or with help from an X-acto knife). Check the attached images to get an idea!

print_settings.Notes:: Please be aware that this piece should be rotated 180°, so that the interruptor hole is facing down. I tried printing it with a Raft with no success, because I was unable to remove it afterwards. After fiddling with the PLA settings, I found that it was best to print it only with a Brim, using 210 degrees for the extruder and 65 for the bed. A slower printed initial layer also helps with the holes which need to be printed (this was the trickiest part).

cOOOOOL CLOCK

My A8 has quite a noisy Y-azis. The 8mm holes in the perspex front and back are fractionally over-sized (if not, assembly would be tricky).

Here is a set of clamps which can replace the tear-drop perspex plates which retain these rods. Use an M3x12 cap-screw to tighten them, and the original M3 bolts to secure them. No need to over-tighten.

Although I didn't observe any significant reduction in the movement of the bed (using a dial gauge, about 0.2mm) this movement is now all from flexig of the rods, not movement. So, it's quieter and maybe smoother at higher speeds.

STL for each corner, or the whole set. There is a mounting for the Y-axis limit switch, and a version of rear-right without this too.

Also added a Z-axis version, which is quite a bit longer.

I made the main hole a little over-sized, for easier fitting, but this shouldn't matter. Use a bit less than 100% infill to make sure it's flexible.

24 May 2017
Updated to add clearance for wing nuts. It is still possible that the wing nuts catch on this clip, so its better to replace them with a normal nut

Depending on how you have the Y axis arranged, and the length of your rods, you might loose a couple of mm of Y travel. With this mod, you can increase the Y offset front/back slightly to compensate.

author: adacoo

description.text:
Android Driedel.
I took the Droidel by mishugana, cut it in half, and added a handle. Unfortunately it doesn't spin very well. It may work better if you give the body a higher infill.

Print the head, body, and stem, then super glue them together with the round part of the stem sticking out the top.  
I split the head and body into separate parts so they could be printed flat side down. I printed both with supports because the head has a small lip that needs supporting and the letters on the body are raised.  
I printed the head and body at 10% infill, but I think the body is too light. I suggest a high infill for the body and some extra shells for good measure.  
The stem needs just a little sanding to fit into the square hole. I made the hole in the body too deep, so you should glue the stem at the desired height in the head before gluing that onto the body.

author: KlausKoeln

title: Audio Technica ATH-M40X Headphone hinge replacement

description.text:
Replacement part designed for Audio Technica ATH-M40X headphones but might work on other similar headphones like M50s (I haven't tested this). If you ask me I would be willing to make a few small changes to the design if its simply widening a hole or something to make it fit, or I can send you the fusion files.

PLEASE READ BEFORE PRINTING

There are 3 parts you need to print, the inner pivot piece, band piece, and outer skin. you will also need 4x M3 x ~5mm long bolts (mine were from an old 'Mechano' toy set), and I can change the dimensions for the bolts you have available if you really can't find any that will work. Also some ~4mm wire/rod (I used a tent peg and cut it down). Additionally you will need some headphone wire and the ability to solder it. there is a <2mm diameter hole to feed this through so most 2 core headphone wire would work, I didn't have any so used individual strands but wouldn't recommend this.

ASSEMBLY:
This is a little awkward,

  1. disassemble the hinge part and cut the wire where it starts to go behind the metal adjustable band. you can see in the last photo how far taken apart it needs to be. Keep all screws and the small plastic part that holds the axle and the metal band.

  2. Cut 4mm rod to length (I think this was ~24mm but don't remember but you can measure this and check it fits yourself)

  3. Finish 3D printed parts - minimal required, maybe some aesthetic sanding and cutting the brim off the inner pivot piece. Fit the rod through this and check it fits with the plastic part over the rod. You will now need to sand down the bottom of the inner pivot piece so it just touches the inside of the bracket when it lines up with the bracket. This acts as the stop for the metal rod pivot.

  4. Solder your wire to the headphone wire and insulate with tape/heatshrink only at one end, and feed it through the hole in the inner pivot piece. Now you can solder the other ends together and check continuity with a multimeter - these wires can be awkward to get a solid joint.

  5. Heat up the metal band with a soldering iron and press the band piece against it to give it a bend. Make sure not to squish it too much as it's easy to buckle it at the cut out for the solder joint.

  6. 'Tap' the holes by heating up the bolts a little and screwing them through the band piece into the outer skin, ensuring both parts are pressed tightly together. Unscrew them enough so the outer skin can be removed.

  7. Press the outer skin over the inner pivot piece and push it down so the small protrusion goes into the slot. push the band piece into place and try to route the wires in its trough so they aren't clamped when you tighten it (this is very fiddly). Insert the metal band once it's cooled down into the slot that's between the skin and inner pivot piece making sure it is all the way to the bottom. Make sure the solder joint is in the cutout in the band piece, now hidden behind the metal band.

  8. Tighten the bolts so the is a only a very small (<1mm) gap between the outer skin and band piece. If there is still a big gap you can try using pliers to bend the tab on the metal band to be less bent. Screw in the screw that was holding the metal band in place before, making sure it goes through the hole in the metal band.

  9. Reassemble. Place the black clip over the band piece (some trimming off the top part with a knife might be needed to get it to fit well) and slide it back into the headphone band. Screw together the plastic ends of the headphone band over the top. File/drill a small hole/slot in the inside part of the headphone cup bracket to pass the wire though and screw back together everything. Finally I pushed the excess wire into the back of this bracket to hide it away.

DONE!! (well except for the other side ;))

PRINTING:
No supports needed for any parts, 2mm wall shell and 1mm top/bottom for strength, 50% infill (there is very little infill volume). Printing time: 1.5-2 hrs.

Inner pivot piece - orient so the axle is facing up and rotate 15 degrees so the bottom surface is on the plate (this is the flat side facing right in the thingview preview), use a brim, 0.15mm layer height

Outer skin - orient so the wide side is o the plate, use 0.1mm layer height for smoothest looking results

Band piece - lay flat (opposite way to how it it in thing view at top), 0.2mm/0.15mm layer height

FEEL FREE TO ASK NY QUESTIONS, I know my instructions aren't great

comments.text:
I knew that it would be much more awkward to print with an axle built in, requiring supports and a lot of finishing to get it round so it rotated smoothly, and even then it wouldn't be as smooth or as strong as a hole and rod. I wanted to make this design last. Plus I had a load of pegs left over from another project so it was just as convenient for me. I also wanted to get them fixed asap since they're my only headphones so I was trying to minimise the time i spent prototyping.
If I get time in the future I will make this adjustment as I understand it can hard for people to source something to use for the rod as well as the screws.

title: The $30 3D scanner V4 - Samsung Edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Remake of Dave Clarke's featured 3D Scanner:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1762299
I modified to meet my needs, add a few "Updates" I found useful, and to fit a Samsung Galaxy S7.
I included the Sketchup File as well in case others find it useful, I typically work scaled up so you'll find a few copies of the components, a scaled up set assembled, a proper sized set assembled, the both broken down to work on as well.

Some Modifications from the original (the ones that I can remember):

• Cog Cover and Main Chassis modified to allow you to "lock" it in place using a couple of short pieces of 1.75mm filament instead of screws seen in other versions.

• Cog Cover modified to have a dropped lip to keep the Cog gear centered, the bearing surface was also enlarged to help with wobble/fit.

• Crank Wheel/Shaft modified to increase the square shaft dimensions slightly to make the fit between it and the Gear slightly tighter.

• Crank Handle parts reworked to add screw threads, the original didn’t fit to well for me and could be improved, this lets you screw the handle parts together and keeps it in place.

• Chassis modified at the stopper/volume control level to fit the Galaxy S7 headphone volume control and provide clearance for the menu button.

• Stopper rebuilt to fit the Galaxy S7 volume control and hit the “Up” volume button consistently.

• Main chassis modified to add a relief to the corners which meet in the middle to add a lip to pry against to aid in part removal

• Cradle modified to fit the Galaxy S7, also fits the S6, S5, S4.

• Chassis modified to fit the slightly larger Galaxy S7 headphone 3.5mm Jack.

Hope you find this useful!

description.text:
This is NOT spare part. Use only for modeling/design accessories for MK8 extruder, primary for Geeetech Prusa i3 pro B.
Complete extruder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2342900

This is the machine Stubby from Nier: Automata released earlier this year. Went ahead and decided to create my own little figurine by extracting photos from the game. Thanks for the views and downloads. If you would like to leave a tip, it would be greatly appreciated. Thanks so much. https://youtu.be/9djKkQPkSZk
Keep a pair of pliers on hand to help push the joints together. But carefully though as to not snap them. Also, keep some acetone or super glue nier by.

Using the camera on my phone, I took pictures of the in-game model. I use them as a reference to aid in modeling. Some details are not 100% accurate due to the camera perspective and distortion from the reference images. So, I improvised and did my best to approximate the design. I hope this prints out well for you. If not please let me know what I can do to help improve its printability.

A tool for pulling bearings from various housings, such as motorbike bearings.

• Break off support structure at entrance to nut trap hole
  • Slip nut into nut trap.
  • Insert 8mm threaded rod (about 600mm should do) into the bottom
  • Twist threaded rod through the nut and into the teeth at the end until tight
  • Insert the teeth into the inside of your bearing
  • Tighten the threaded rod till its very tight (But dont break the teeth!)
  • Pull upwards like crazy (Or better yet, put a nut on your threaded rod and a block of wood with an 10mm hole in it and then use it as a hammer to bang upwards onto the nut.
    • Its parametric, but currently configured to do the bearings on my dirt bike.

author: dutchmogul

title: PLA - Micro Kwad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
PLA Micro Kwad
I love my blade inductrix, pushing the limits of my flying skills enviably means that I end up breaking a lot of frames... And awhile ago inductrix frames were reasonably cheap, but now they are nearly £8 + P&P. So, I got to thinking wouldn't be great if I could print a frame whenever I needed one, in whatever colour I felt like...

This design does, therefore, provides a temporary solution for those weekends when you break your frame, you have no spares, & the shops are closed. Now you can print your own frame until you can order a new one. And more importantly, it keeps you flying whilst waiting for your new frame to arrive...

The design has taken a few weeks to perfect, and I still have a little work to do, to make it a little lighter... But the good news is I know have a fully flying Micro Kwad that I can print in any colour I choose from Rigid.ink great range, in either ABS, PLA, or PLA+ for about a £1, including; frame, & camera, battery, motor mounts. I am now using TPU for the camera mount, and motor mounts too...

Flight times - Well, I'm getting a good 3 min flight time, and plenty of power, with an all up weight of the parts (without the motors, camera or FC); PLA Micro Kwad @ 8g, compared to the: Ragg-E @ 7g, Lynx Heli @ 6g, Inductrix Frame @ 5g...

So, in summary, this design allows you to print your own frame in 1 hour & 15 mins for a £1! How cool is that? The range of colours from Rigid allows you to really personalise your model to suit your personality or mood;-)

I would like to say a big thank you to Cemal Kucuk AKA DroneJunkie for all his help and good advice whilst designing this frame and especially the remix of his motor cap design. Go & visit http://www.dronejunkie.co.uk for all the latest aftermarket parts for your Micro Kwad.

I hope you have as much fun with this design as I have had designing it!

And as always I would really appreciate your thoughts, comments and feedback...

Please Enjoy! And please post pictures of your builds too...

The kit I used

  1. Micro AIO Camera 5.8G 25mW https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06XK9KX1Z/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?smid=AP0ABZZM4QKJV&psc=1
  2. NewBeeDrone - BeeBrain v.1 - Micro Brushed Flight Controller - http://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop/the-beebrain-v1-2-from-newbeedrone/
  3. NewBeeDrone -BDR Gold edition brushed 6mm motor - https://newbeedrone.com/collections/beeductrix-inductrix/products/bee-dynamic-rotor-gold-edition-6x15mm-brushed-motor-set
  4. CL-0615-17 MMW Coreless Brushed motor x4 (Reds) - http://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop/cl-0615-17-mmw-coreless-brushed-motor-x4-red-edition/
  5. NewBeeDrone - NitroNectar Power - Nitro Nectar 250mAh HV LiPo Battery - https://newbeedrone.com/collections/lipobatteries/products/newbeedrone-high-voltage-nitro-nectar-210-30-60c-mah-battery
  6. Mylipo 240mAh 4.35V HV 25C / 50C mcpX (PW) - http://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop/mylipo-240mah-4-35v-hv-25c-50c-mcpx-pw/
  7. PLA, or PLA+ from Rigid Ink https://rigid.ink/products/flexible-pla-1-75-mm-0-03-mm-tolerance-filament?variant=34085486279
  8. 14 x M1.2 mm 3mm PANS Head Screw Silver - https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01M1CI4PA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Existing Frames

  1. Blade Inductrix frames £7.55 + P&P - https://www.horizonhobby.co.uk/Blade-Inductrix-Main-Frame.htm?SessionId=&a=article&ProdNr=094BLH8706&gclid=Cj0KEQjwgODIBRCEqfv60eq65ogBEiQA0ZC5-ftdY8J0-_P3PCz6qQ4jjNpS39kilN2cnSsRdI6oqNYaAsJ68P8HAQ
  2. Ragg-E Micro FPV £19.99 + P&P - http://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop/ragg-e-whoop-frame-set/
  3. Lynx Heli Spider 65 FPV Racer $19.95 + P&P https://www.lynxheli.com/index.php?cPath=373_367_395&osCsid=64d41eeaa5639bca63fe8c1bfe030469

Design inspiration...

  1. Blade Inductrix the Orignal Micro Kwad -http://www.bladehelis.com/Inductrix/
    https://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop
  2. Cemal Kucuk AKA DroneJunkie - [email protected] - Motor Cap Design Inspiration! Cemal is a Micro Drone expert, and his shop supplies; aftermarket part, drones, spare & good advice and all round good guy!
  3. Microdure - https://www.facebook.com/Microdure/
  4. Tom Ashley - Ragg-E Micro FPV - http://www.ragg-e.co.uk/micro-quad-frames
  5. Lynx Heli Spider 65 FPV Racer - https://www.lynxheli.com/index.php?cPath=373_367_395&osCsid=64d41eeaa5639bca63fe8c1bfe030469

Please follow me...
Twitter - @heliboy
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/DavidOwensuk
YouTube - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCu8jFGkgTAqEUlK7dj1jhxw
Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/dowens234/

As always please; download, like and subscribe... Please feedback if you would like changes made to the design.

Printer:

Vector V3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I would like to suggest you use Rigid Ink https://rigid.ink/products/flexible-pla-1-75-mm-0-03-mm-tolerance-filament?variant=34085486279

If you are using www.rigid.ink then following settings apply

Print at: 190 to 210 degrees celsius
Heated bed: 40 to 60 degrees celsius
Notes: Adheres well to Buildtak bed https://www.buildtak.eu

Felting

Once the parts are printed drill out all of the screw holes using a 1mm drill, and the motor holes with 6mm drill. It is always a good idea to trim or clean the rough edges off any model, especially a 3D printed one... When installing the motors into the frame you will feel a positive click when they reach the end stop. I will try and upload a build video in the next few days.

Designed with Fusion 360, printed using Simplify3D

description.text:
Someone asked if I could make a Captured PENNY Fidget Spinner to go along withmy Captured Nickle and Captured Quarter spinners. So, here it is. There is a file for ABS or PLA.

Use your favorite button or one of mine, either ABS or PLA.

I used Fusion 360 for this design.

Designed for 2 pennies in each hole making my cost $0.79 ( 6 pennies, 1 bearing, plastic)

THIS REQUIRES THAT YOU PAUSE THE PRINTER AT ABOUT 60% TO DROP THE PENNIES IN.

Link to bearings that I used https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C9XDPVQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Link to Pennies that I used
https://www.usmint.gov/

Print Settings

Printer:
Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:
No

Supports:
No

Resolution:
0.2

Infill:
20 - 100

Notes:
at about 60% complete you need to pause the printing and drop the pennies in
use 2 pennies per coin hole
make sure you have the sides of the coins showing that you want
CAUTION - the pennies hold the heat from the bed alot longer than the plastic

title: Game Clip for Xbox 360
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix from this:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1648234

And this:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82950

It needs:

4x Allen M3 x 40 mm (or 36) bolts
1x Allen M3 x 60 mm bolt
4x Allen M3 x 12 mm bolts
2x Hex M3 x 120 mm (or 100) bolts (i)
11x M3 regular nuts (ii)
6x M3 washers (iii)
2x springs (iv)

(i) These are not easy to find, M3 threaded rod with two nuts on the bottom side and one on the top side should do the job.

(ii) Better have 15 or more nuts.

(iii) Better have 14 or more washers, in case you want to add another 8 to fix the clip to the gamepad.

(iv) They should be 30mm long and fit around a M3 bolt.

You have to print one of each piece except for the Beam (2 of this).
Works for any phone over 70mm wide and could easily be used with wider phones as long as the vertical bolts are long enough.

comments.author: StefanDB

comments.text: Hi Thomas,
comments.author: ThomasQ6

comments.text: Here are a picture of the first attempt (in white), a small amount of the white spaghetti (I left this one running over night), and all the spaghetti from the second print. I'm printing in PLA, and used 215 hot end, 55 deg bed (first and subsequent) layers. I got these from the bundled print settings; the other settings I guessed at.
comments.author: StefanDB

comments.text: One of the first things I would suggest is to bring down the bed temperature after the first layer (too room temperature). keeping it at 55 all the way through can be an issue, since PLA starts to yield around 60deg. Also, I believe I printed at 198 deg on the hot end. What's the scale of your print?
comments.author: ThomasQ6

title: UTILITECH LED Light Mic-Stand frame attachment

description.text:
Have a UTILITECH 10 Watt LED light you want to use with your mic stand? Look no further! This fast printing and super lightweight design will get you mounting your light to a mic-stand in seconds! (After the print, of course). monocle

The screw I used to brace the frame to the stand is a 3.8mm bolt. It came with the Anet A8 kit.

I'm going to be honest and say this frame is somewhat flimsy. It's perfect for how you see the light positioned in the photo. If you're just going to leave it like that and move the stand around you'll be totally fine.

I didn't want to wait five hours for the original I had originally made, so I slimmed it right down to the minimum for a "one hour" print.

Fusion 360

I am learning how to design models in Fusion 360. This is my very first simple design, but I was dying to make something that would hold this little LED light up on a stand for spot fills with lighting.

title: Prehistoric Shark Tooth (Fossil)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a fossilized prehistoric shark tooth from an "Otodus obliquus" shark, Eocen time period (About 50 million years ago).
The fossil was found in Khourigba, Marocko.
If I have my facts straight the Ododus obliquus is a predecessor to the more well known giant Megalodon shark that I also posted a scanned tooth from some time ago.
The fossil was a gift from a friend and shark enthusiast that host the Lamna.se website where you can find more things shark related.
The fossil was scanned using Agisoft standard edition photoscan software at normal setting. The model still turned out quite detailed. Mine printed well from the uploaded stl file, just set your preferred printer settings and don't forget to use supports. Happy printing and enjoy! If you like it and make one please let me know.

title: Filament Spool Bracket Spinner - 608 Bearing System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a bracket for mounting a filament spool - although you need two to make it work. It's designed to use 608 skateboard bearings to reduce resistance and allow your filament to be pulled smoothly into the extruder.

The file was designed for printing in ABS so dimensions are slightly oversized to ensure a press fit for the bearing.

Build Guide:
Fit the bearings. Slide 2 spinners into the sides of the filament spool, slide some M8 threaded rod through each spinner, fit a washer on from each end, secure each end with an M8 nut. Print.

I'd use the v2 version for simplicity when printing.

*NOTE: I do NOT claim to have anything to do with the creation of this model. I only downloaded it for free from TurboSquid.com, and wanted desperately to see it come to life. This is an incredibly detailed model of the famed Lost City of Atlantis, as depicted in the fantastic SciFi series, Stargate Atlantis. It's level of detail is far beyond what I believe any fan to be capable of, which makes me wonder if it's the actual model from the show?! :D Regardless, it needs to be printed! But alas, it is considerably beyond my ability to slice into printable build trays. Is anyone out there up to the task? :D Cheers!

Just designed this prop bumper for my babyhawk so I can reduce weight and still have some protection. I have not printed it yet and don't know how much weight it saves. It's designed to be 1.5mm thick where the mounting screws are so it should allow the reuse of the same screws without interfering with the motors. But always measure yours to be sure.

*** Edited the screw hole spacing. Made an error laying it out originally. Should be 8.3mm center to center diagonally.

*** Opened up the center hole as the BH has a short tube under the motor. The hole alignment was good but I felt like it was too heavy and overly built so I created a lighter V2 version. two of the V2 guards weigh 2.36 grams compared to the original 3.55 grams.

description.text:
"The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is the human warrior, you need to print 3 to make a game stand. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

description.text:
GeoConstructix

GeoConstructix can be used to build a beautiful geometric paper sculpture.

GeoConstructix can also be used as a STEM learning tool to help students learn the fundamentals of geometry and engineering.

Manufacturing
Use a laser print to cut out the following triangles, squares, pentagons, and hexagons using cardstock. Geometric sculptures can be assembled using rubber bands.

Educational
Lessons plans aligned with common core can be found below.

Materials:
8.5x11 inch Cardstock - 110 lb
11x17 Inch Cardstock - 110lb - Required for Pentagon and Hexagon
Rubber bands - 2.5 inch (approx)

Lesson Plans
GeoConstructix can be used by students ages 9-18 to learn the fundamentals of engineering and geometry. Build complex free form sculptures or use the following lesson plans to help guide students through critical concepts
GeoConstructix Lesson Plan - Grade 7 - Area - Volume - Surface Area
CCSS

Overview GeoConstructix are an adaptable learning tool which can be used to build beautiful sculptures or lamp shades. They can be used by students of all ages to help teach the fundamentals of geometry and engineering. Use LED lights such as Adafruit Neopixels to create a creative light and teach electronics and programming.

Student Lesson Plans GeoConstructix can be used to help students visualize a wide array of fundamental concepts in geometry. Lesson plans are continuing to be developed for different age groups. GeoConstructix Lesson Plan - Grade 7 - Area - Volume - Surface Area

Materials Required The following materials are required to manufacture GeoConstructix 8.5x11 Cardstock - 110 lb - Various Colors add to visual effect
11x17 Cardstock - 110lb

description.text:
Work in Progress. Your ideas and comments are welcomed!

June 2017:

I Made it easier to print and added an end stop. No need for support. If you use the new model and you print in ABS, increase the size by 10% to make it less likely to break. The size, as is, is fine for nylon.

My goal is an actual zipper, that you could iron onto cotton tape and actually sew into something.

May 2017:

I too felt the urge to see how close I could get to a real zipper. Why? Because it seemed like it would be hard to do. It works pretty well, but I had to go through about a dozen iterations.

I am quickly learning the limits of tiny FDM printed parts. Make something too thin, it breaks too easily, make it too thick and the zipper is not flexible enough.

I have made it possible to sew it onto cloth. Or maybe even ironing it onto cloth. I am not at the point of trying that yet.

There are many caveats about this model. Mostly, the dimensions are too thin in places. You can break things just removing the supports. I will likely make it slightly bigger.

I will make a few modifications, so stay tuned. I may add end stops, etc. If I can get it a little more easy to build, I will parameterize it in SCAD.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The model is sized for nylon. If you print in ABS, increase the size by 10%

I used a raft because the teeth are really small, and there are many of them. The first layer has almost no footprint for the teeth, and I tried several times to get this started with no success. As far as I know, a raft is required. I used the base layers and 2 top layers.

There are thin walls and rails that need to be filled in. Check the slicer to make sure that the thin parts do not have a hollow interior.

Removing supports. Gluing the thumb thing to the slide.

Tricky. Tricky!

The supports are holding up thin walls that are easily broken. Remove them slowly, carefully.

I have no idea why I arranged the two sides of the zipper to be interlocked when printed. When you pull them apart, you can begin by gently rolling them between your thumb and finger to break them apart a bit. If you separate the top two teeth by that magic angle, they begin to unzip.

I super glued the thumb thing to the top of the slider.
Drawn from scratch in Blender.
